newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: TENNIS-HENMAN FACES CHANG IN THIRD-ROUND SHOWDOWN.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-HENMAN FACES CHANG IN THIRD-ROUND SHOWDOWN.

text.p: British hopeful Tim Henman will put his rapidly improving game to the test on Friday night in a third- round showdown with Australian Open second seed Michael Chang.

Henman, carrying the hopes of a success-starved nation after his quarter-final appearance in Wimbledon last year, is looking to do even better at Melbourne Park but must first beat Chang at one of the world number two's favourite venues.

Billed as the day's biggest centre court attraction, the match will pit the two players against each other for the first time and give Henman a chance to build on the promising form which has him leading the 1997 win lists.
The 22-year-old Briton is on a high after beating world number four Goran Ivanisevic on the way to winning the tournament in Sydney last week.
So too is Chang, who beat world number one Pete Sampras in an exhibition match last weekend, though he was not completely content with his first two victories here.
Chang, a finalist here last year, has not tasted grand slam success since winning the French Open as a 17-year-old in 1989.

In other matches, seventh seed Thomas Enqvist, Sweden's flagbearer after the retirement of Stefan Edberg, will fight to turn the tide of history when he meets Spain's Sergi Bruguera in a third round encounter on centre court.
Bruguera has won all their three previous matches.

Women's world number one Steffi Graf should have no trouble in her seemingly predestined march to the Open final. She plays Argentina's Ines Gorrochategui, ranked 97 places below her, for a place in the final 16.
